tasks.task: Use a spade to dig a trench for a row of plants.
subtasks: Approach the farm area.
Pick up a spade.
Walk to the designated planting row.
Bend down or kneel to begin digging.
Hold the spade with both hands.
Start the digging motion, pushing the spade into the ground.
Use leg power to lift the spade and break up the soil.
Repeat digging along the desired trench length.
Check the depth of the trench.
Remove excess soil if the trench is too deep or too shallow.
Straighten the trench for even planting depth.
Step back or crouch down to assess the trench’s preparation.
Put down the spade.

tasks.task: Plant seedlings into the prepared trench.
subtasks: Retrieve seedlings or plants from storage.
Hold the seedlings carefully by the roots or stems.
Kneel or crouch next to the trench.
Align a seedling with the center of the trench.
Gently lower the seedling into the trench, ensuring straight alignment.
Fill in the space around the seedling with soil.
Use fingers or a tool to firm the soil around the base.
Repeat for each seedling in the trench.

tasks.task: Water the newly planted row.
subtasks: Collect a watering can or sprinkler from the nearby equipment.
Carry the watering device to the planted row.
Open the watering device.
Start watering the base of each plant.
Ensure even distribution of water along the row.
Close the watering device after finishing.

tasks.task: Spread mulch over the planted area.
subtasks: Retrieve mulch material (e.g., straw, bark chips).
Spread mulch evenly over the soil surface between rows.
Walk along the rows, distributing mulch uniformly.
Press down lightly on the mulch to secure it.

tasks.task: Prune a shrub or tree.
subtasks: Identify branches to prune on the shrub or tree.
Approach the base of the shrub or tree.
Use pruning shears or a saw to cut the selected branches.
Dispose of the pruned branches (e.g., by placing them in a pile).
Step back to verify the pruning has opened up airflow and light penetration.
Apply fungicide or other treatment to the pruning wounds if needed.

tasks.task: Operate a combine harvester to harvest crops.
subtasks: Enter the combine harvester.
Attach the correct header for the crop being harvested.
Position the combine in the field.
Begin driving the combine through the crops.
Adjust the combine’s settings to optimize harvest efficiency.
Monitor the harvested grain or produce.
Load the combine after each pass.
Operate the unloading mechanism to transfer the crop to a waiting bin.

tasks.task: Apply fertilizer to a field.
subtasks: Load fertilizer into a spreader.
Hitch the spreader to a tractor or other power source.
Drive the spreader through the field, following the desired patterns.
Adjust the spreader’s discharge rate based on soil and crop needs.
Check for even distribution and adjust as necessary.
Clear any clogs or issues during operation.

tasks.task: Prepare a raised garden bed.
subtasks: Choose a location for the garden bed.
Gather materials such as wood, stones, or bricks.
Lay out the materials to form the frame of the garden bed.
Fill the bed with soil, tamping it down as needed.
Install drainage holes or channels if necessary.
Apply mulch or organic matter on the surface.
Plant seeds or seedlings in the prepared bed.

tasks.task: Inspect farm animals for health issues.
subtasks: Walk through the animal quarters (stables, pens).
Examine each animal closely.
Check for signs of illness or injury (e.g., lame legs, discharge).
Take vital signs if possible (temperature, pulse).
Note any deviations from normal behavior.
Document observations for further action or treatment.

tasks.task: Clean a barn or animal shelter.
subtasks: Open doors and windows to ventilate the space.
Sweep and clean floors, removing debris and manure.
Wash stalls or pens with water and cleaning agents.
Check for leaks or other structural issues.
Replace bedding material (straw, shavings) if necessary.
Organize supplies and equipment in the area.
Remove any accumulated trash or debris.

tasks.task: Service farm machinery.
subtasks: Inspect machinery for wear or damage before use.
Check fluid levels (oil, coolant, fuel).
Lubricate moving parts according to the manufacturer’s schedule.
Replace filters or perform other routine maintenance tasks.
Test machinery operation to ensure proper functioning.

tasks.task: Operate a hay baler to harvest hay.
subtasks: Set up the hay baler in a field.
Cut the hay using the baler’s tine or cutter bar.
Guide the hay into the baler, making sure it is loaded properly.
Engage the baler mechanism to form the hay into a bale.
Discharge the bale from the baler.
Repeat the process as needed until the field is harvested.

tasks.task: Install irrigation pipes for a garden.
subtasks: Measure the garden area to determine pipe layout.
Lay out irrigation pipes along the planting rows.
Secure pipes in place with stakes or clips.
Connect the ends of pipes to a water source.
Test the system for leaks or proper flow.
Install emitters or sprinkler heads as needed.

tasks.task: Prepare seeds for planting.
subtasks: Collect clean seed from storage or generation.
Remove any debris or damaged seeds.
Sort seeds by type or quality if needed.
Store treated seeds properly before planting.

tasks.task: Harvest ripe fruits or vegetables from a garden.
subtasks: Identify ripened produce in the garden area.
Approach the plant or vine where the produce is located.
Gently grasp the produce, checking for maturity.
Pick the produce, ensuring not to damage the plant.
Place harvested items into a basket or container.
Repeat for all ripe produce in the garden.

tasks.task: Prepare a irrigation system for a new field.
subtasks: Survey the field to determine water source proximity.
Locate potential pipe runs and pathways.
Consult with an engineer or agronomist for design.
Purchase necessary materials (pipes, fittings, control valves).
Install pipes and fittings following proper installation techniques.
Test the system for functionality before planting.

tasks.task: Mow overgrown areas of a field or garden.
subtasks: Choose the appropriate mower for the terrain (lawn mower, brush cutter).
Load the mower onto a vehicle or bring it to the area.
Set up the mower if necessary (adjusting height, etc.).
Begin mowing the overgrown areas, moving the mower systematically.
Cut back tall grass, weeds, or invasive plants.
Dispose of cuttings if needed (compost, remove from site).

tasks.task: Apply fungicide to a vineyard.
subtasks: Mix the fungicide concentrate with water as per instructions.
Fill a sprayer with the prepared solution.
Calibrate the sprayer for optimal coverage.
Attach the sprayer system to the tractor or ground equipment.
Drive the sprayer through the vine rows, applying the fungicide.
Stop regularly to check spray coverage and adjust as needed.

tasks.task: Prepare a silo for storing grain.
subtasks: Check the silo structure for safety and stability.
Clean the interior of the silo.
Install breathable screens or plastic if required.
Load grain into the silo using a conveyor or directly.
Compact the grain to eliminate air pockets.
Ensure the silo doors are secure.

tasks.task: Build a chicken coop.
subtasks: Gather materials such as wood, roofing, insulation.
Plan the layout and measurements for the coop.
Assemble the frame work with nails or screws.
Install the roofing to create the shelter.
Add ventilation and appropriate perches for the chickens.

tasks.task: Winterize farm equipment.
subtasks: Drain and replace coolant and oil in tractors and other machinery.
Cover exposed parts with protective covers.
Store tires and other parts indoors if possible.
Clean and lubricate equipment to prevent rust and corrosion.
Inspect electrical systems and replace any damaged wiring.

tasks.task: Prepare a livestock drinking water system.
subtasks: Check the water source (well, pond, tank) for sufficient supply.
Inspect the water pipes or lines for leaks or blockages.
Clean water troughs or automatic drinkers.
Repair or replace any damaged components.
Test the system to ensure all parts function correctly.

tasks.task: Conduct routine soil testing to monitor nutrient levels.
subtasks: Take soil samples from different areas of the farm.
Send the samples to a laboratory for analysis.
Receive and interpret the results to determine nutrient needs.
Amend the soil as needed with fertilizers or lime.

tasks.task: Observe a crop field for pests or diseases.
subtasks: Walk through the field at various times, looking for signs of stress.
Check the underside of leaves for pests or disease signs.
Take notes on the presence and severity of issues.
Consult reference materials or Extension Services for identification and management.
Plan appropriate control measures based on observations.

tasks.task: Install a fence around a property to protect crops or livestock.
subtasks: Survey the perimeter and determine fence specifications.
Prepare the ground by clearing brush and grading.
Install fence posts and anchors.
Stretch wire or mesh between the posts, ensuring proper tension.
Secure the bottom wire or band to prevent animals from digging under.
Check fencing materials for durability and safety.

tasks.task: Repair a broken fence panel.
subtasks: Locate the damaged panel in the fence.
Remove the broken pieces from the fence line.

Install the new panel, aligning it with neighboring panels.

tasks.task: Construct a compost bin.
subtasks: Choose a site away from the garden but accessible for use.

Monitor moisture levels and adjust watering if needed.

Cover the entire garden, carefully following the label’s instructions.

title: Grazing Systems

tasks.task: Implementing integrated rangeland management techniques involving different grazing systems.
subtasks: Placing livestock in designated pastures or rotation schedules, ensuring proper timing of grazing and rest periods on rangeland.

Adjusting stocking rates and herd distribution to accommodate seasonal changes and environmental factors.
Utilizing rest rotation systems by allowing pastures to recover for a year before resuming grazing.
Employing continuous grazing systems where livestock are allowed to graze a single pasture year-round with limited supervision.
Rotating grazing pastures using deferred rotation systems, where at least one pasture is left ungrazed per season to recover.
Implementing high-intensity grazing systems with short-duration grazing periods to stimulate plant regrowth and distribute grazing pressure evenly.
Adapting grazing methods to local climate and vegetation conditions, utilizing decisional systems based on real-time availability of forage.
Coordinating grazing practices with other management activities such as haying, prescribed burns, and animal reproduction cycles.
Maintaining flexibility in grazing plans to address unexpected events such as wildfires, invasive species, drought, or wildlife presence.
